Netanyahu’s move is the latest illustration of how coronavirus vaccines have emerged as a kind of diplomatic currency

Fourth Quarter 2020 Investor Slides Available Online Investor slides reviewing Infinera's fourth quarter of 2020 financial results will be furnished to the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) on a Current Report on Form 8-K and published on Infinera's Investor Relations website at investors. infinera. com prior to the fourth quarter of 2020 earnings conference call.  Analysts and investors are encouraged to review these slides prior to participating in the conference call webcast.  Conference Call Information Infinera will host a conference call for analysts and investors to discuss its results for the fourth quarter of 2020 and its outlook for the first quarter of 2021 today at 5:00 p. m.  Eastern Time (2:00 p. m.  Pacific Time).  Interested parties may join the conference call by dialing 1-866-373-6878 (toll free) or 1-412-317-5101 (international).  A live webcast of the conference call will also be accessible from the Events section of Infinera’s website at investors. infinera. com.  Replay of the audio webcast will be available at investors. infinera. com approximately two hours after the end of the live call. column416: 984 (1)Business combination accounting principles require Infinera to write down to fair value its maintenance support contracts assumed in Infinera's acquisition of Coriant
column417: which closed during the fourth quarter of 2018.  The revenue for these support contracts is deferred and typically recognized over a period of time after the Coriant acquisition
column418: so Infinera's GAAP revenue for a period of time after the acquisition will not reflect the full amount of revenue that would have been reported if the acquired deferred revenue was not written down to fair value.  The non-GAAP adjustment eliminates the effect of the deferred revenue write-down.  Management believes these adjustments to revenue from support contracts assumed in the Coriant acquisition are useful to investors as an additional means to reflect revenue trends in Infinera's business. column477: the reduction of headcount at Infinera's Munich
column479: and Coriant's historical restructuring plan associated with its early retirement plan.  In addition
column480: this includes accelerated amortization on operating lease right-of-use assets due to the cessation of use of certain facilities.  Management has excluded the impact of these charges in arriving at Infinera's non-GAAP results as they are non-recurring in nature and its exclusion provides a better indication of Infinera's underlying business performance.  (8)COVID-19 related costs consist of higher replacement costs associated with certain warranty parts customers were unable to return for repair due to logistics issues and mobility issues related to COVID-19 public health mandates and restrictions.  In addition
column481: Infinera needed to source certain key components from an alternate supplier at substantially higher cost in order to fulfill delivery commitments in the normal course of business.  Management has excluded these expenses from non-GAAP financial measures because they were caused by atypical circumstances during the COVID-19 pandemic
column482: as their exclusion provides a better indication of Infinera's underlying business performance.  (9)Litigation charges are associated with the preliminary settlement of a litigation matter agreed to during the quarter ended June 29
column483: 2019.  Management has excluded the impact of this charge in arriving at Infinera's non-GAAP results because it is non-recurring and management believes that this expense is not indicative of ongoing operating performance.  (10)Under GAAP
column484: certain convertible debt instruments that may be settled in cash on conversion are required to be separately accounted for as liability (debt) and equity (conversion option) components of the instrument in a manner that reflects the issuer's non-convertible debt borrowing rate.  Accordingly
column486: Infinera is required to amortize as debt discount an amount equal to the fair value of the conversion option that was recorded in equity as interest expense on the $402. 5 million in aggregate principal amount of its 2. 125% convertible debt issuance in September 2018 due September 2024 and $200 million in aggregate principal amount of 2. 50% convertible debt issued in March 9
column487: 2020 due March 2027.  Interest expense has been excluded from Infinera's non-GAAP results because management believes that this non-cash expense is not indicative of ongoing operating performance and its exclusion provides a better indication of Infinera's underlying business performance.  (11)Management has excluded the gain on the sale related to non-marketable equity investments in arriving at Infinera's non-GAAP results because it is non-recurring
column488: and management believes that this income is not indicative of ongoing operating performance (12)The difference between the GAAP and non-GAAP tax provision is due to the net tax effects of the purchase accounting adjustments
column489: acquisition-related costs and amortization of acquired intangible assets.  (13)Non-GAAP EPS as adjusted did not exclude the impact of foreign currency.  Had the impact of foreign currency been excluded for the three months ended December 26
column494: non-GAAP EPS as adjusted would have been $0. 08
column495: loss of less than one cent
column498: and for the twelve months ended December 26
column501: non-GAAP EPS as adjusted would have been $(0. 19) and $(0. 57)
column502: respectively.  (14)The non-GAAP diluted shares include the potentially dilutive securities from Infinera's stock-based benefit plans excluded from the computation of dilutive net loss per share attributable to common stockholders on a GAAP basis because the effect would have been anti-dilutive.  These potentially dilutive securities are added for the computation of diluted net income per share on a non-GAAP basis in periods when Infinera has net income on a non-GAAP basis.  During the three months ended December 26
column504: the Company included the dilutive effects of the 2027 Notes in the calculation of diluted net income per common share as the average market price was above the conversion price of the Notes.  The dilutive impact of the Notes was based on the difference between the Company's average stock price during the period and the conversion price of the Notes. column1: 2021-02-24 10:46:03#business#Wells Fargo Inks Deal To Sell Asset Management Arm For $2.1B#https://finance.yahoo.com/news/wells-fargo-inks-deal-sell-104603489.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/1Rz6Ws086BPTglIJcsbpPQ--~B/aD00NDg7dz04MTE7YXBwaWQ9eXRhY2h5b24-/https://media.zenfs.com/en/smarteranalyst_347/20402b6a1ffe2f727a69347cd8fd3295#en#0.5423#finance.yahoo.com#Wells Fargo has agreed to sell Wells Fargo Asset Management (WFAM) to private-equity firms – GTCR and Reverence Capital Partners – for $2. 1 billion.  WFAM is the asset management unit of the bank
column2: with $603 billion in assets under management and specialized investment teams with more than 450 investment professionals.  The deal is anticipated to close in the second half of 2021.  Per the terms of the transaction
column3: Wells Fargo (WFC) will continue to serve as a client and distribution partner
column4: holding a 9. 9% equity interest.  Wells Fargo’s Wealth & Investment Management division CEO Barry Sommers said
column5: “Operating as an independent firm as a portfolio company of GTCR and Reverence Capital will provide numerous benefits to WFAM’s clients
column7: and strategic partners — including Wells Fargo. ” (See Wells Fargo stock analysis on TipRanks) “At the same time
column8: this transaction reflects Wells Fargo’s strategy to focus on businesses that serve our core consumer and corporate clients
column9: and will allow us to focus even more on growing our wealth and brokerage businesses
column11: J. P.  Morgan analyst Vivek Juneja upgraded the stock to Hold from Sell and increased the price target to $37 from $31. 50 following “news reports that the Federal Reserve accepted the company’s plan to overhaul its risk management and compliance
column12: which is a critical step on the path to eventual lifting of the asset cap. ” Juneja believes the company’s “valuation is appropriate after factoring in potential earnings benefit from lifting of the asset cap plus sizable cost savings from its restructuring. ” However
column14: “there is still much uncertainty about the full earnings run rate and profitability once the restructuring is completed. ” The rest of the Street is cautiously optimistic about the stock with a Moderate Buy consensus rating.  That’s based on 11 analysts suggesting a Buy and 8 analysts recommending a Hold.  The average analyst price target of $36. 63 implies 1% downside potential to current levels.  Shares have gained 58. 3% over the past six months. column1: 2021-02-23 21:55:09#tech#The development of Dying Light 2 has been 'total chaos
column2: ' according to report#https://www.pcgamer.com/the-development-of-dying-light-2-has-been-total-chaos-according-to-report/#https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/qR99xjfDtqMDwMzzmUtXA5-1200-80.jpg#en#0.0#www.pcgamer.com#"Dying Light 2 has had its share of struggles since it was announced almost three years ago at E3 2018.  Developer Techland made some very big promises regarding the impact of individual player choice on gameplay and outcomes
column3: which would demand multiple playthroughs for anyone who wanted to see more than half of the content it offered.  But a planned release for spring 2020 was missed
column4: and a new release date hasn't been set.  The game also lost its lead writer
column6: who departed earlier this year after more than 20 years at the studio. A new report on Techland published by TheGamer suggests that the project may be floundering largely due to problems at the studio
column7: particularly regarding the ""autocratic"" management style of CEO Pawel Marchewka.  Interviews with ten current and former employees allege problems including an over-reliance on external consultants who lack experience in the games industry (whose advice is often ignored anyway)
column8: conflict at the production level
column9: a high rate of staff turnover
column10: and micromanagement that some developers characterized as ""the eye of Sauron
column11: which has collectively had the effect of stripping the game of a ""coherent vision. ""Techland has a history of hiring people for which the team had 'high hopes
column12: ' but it ended up in nothing
column13: one source said.  ""One such case for the designers was the hiring of Marc Albinet
column14: a former game director from Ubisoft
column15: that was supposed to restructure how design is done in the studio.  Even he
column16: a veteran with 30 years of experience
column17: couldn't break through upper management that is harder to change than the spin of the fucking Earth. ""New hires and consultant who don't follow the company line end up sidelined
column19: which ultimately leads to their resignation or termination: ""To make a career at Techland
column20: you have to be subservient. ""Techland's insistence on using its own internal technology to power the game is also a stumbling block
column21: according to some employees.  Dying Light uses the Chrome Engine
column22: a proprietary 3D engine developed by Techland
column23: but after the first game was released the chief development officer at the time
column25: wanted development of the sequel to be iterated in a more widely used engine
column27: before bringing their work to the Chrome Engine.  Marchewka
column29: insisted on everything being done in Chrome Engine 6. ""It slowed everyone down and that frustrated everyone
column30: a source told TheGamer.  ""He would ask why people aren't working faster and it was because the tech isn’t up to speed.  We can work faster
column31: but we have to go here
column32: and you're not allowing us to go there.  The experts know what the goal is
column33: and they should be allowed the flexibility to do what’s best. ""Zawodny
column34: who now heads up CD Projekt Red's Wroclaw studio
column35: brought on consultants of his own to help build a more conventional workflow
column36: but many of their suggestions were apparently not adopted.  The system as it currently stands
column38: is ""a production pipeline that changes so quickly and rapidly that it might as well not exist. "" More producers have been hired to help get the wheels turning
column39: but reportedly often find their efforts blocked be veteran employees. The report touches on a range of other issues
column40: such as producers interfering in design decisions—one source said producers on Dying Light 2 ""cannot hold the pipeline or milestones together
column41: but they [have] time to redesign or argue about design""—and constant micromanagement from upper management
column42: which collectively points to an atmosphere of chaos and aimlessness at the studio
column43: and on Dying Light 2. ""What is going on in Techland is just total chaos
column45: a source said.  ""There are plenty of examples where there is someone responsible for a given feature—like a game director decides on something—but Pyza [creative director Adrian 'Pyza' Ciszewski] and Marchewka just overwrite this because of some bullshit reason
column46: like they've seen something working differently in other games so we can do it like that. ""Marchewka defended the studio and its processes
column47: saying that ""trust and the flow of ideas in a large organization is a complex issue. ""We are currently working on creating an innovative game that millions of players around the world will love
column48: and thus we are constantly looking for methods that allow us to improve the transmission of fresh and interesting ideas
column50: not every idea is a good idea for this project
column51: and only the best and consistent ones with the vision of the project will be implemented in our game. ”Unfortunately
column52: there's still no sign of a Dying Light 2 release date: Techland said in January when it confirmed Selinger's departure that it would ""be sharing exciting news about Dying Light 2 soon
column53: but as of now there's been no sign of what that news might be.  I've reached out to Techland for comment
column54: and will update if I receive a reply. "#https://www.pcgamer.com/the-development-of-dying-light-2-has-been-total-chaos-according-to-report/#BXodmttyB

column1: 2021-02-23 00:15:00#tech#PS5 Controller Teardown Points To Reason For DualSense Drift#https://www.ign.com/videos/ps5-controller-teardown-points-to-reason-for-dualsense-drift-ign-daily-fix#https://assets1.ignimgs.com/thumbs/userUploaded/2021/2/22/dailyfix-022221blogroll-1614039323009.jpg?width=1280#en#0.0#www.ign.com#In today’s episode of the Daily Fix
column2: Sydnee tries to explain what the folks at iFixIt think causes drift in the PlayStation 5 DualSense controller.  It’s all pretty technical
column3: but in the most basic of terms
column4: it’s wear-and-tear on some of the components.  Another interesting thing to come out of the PS5 controller teardown: the company that supplies joysticks for the PS5 Dual Sense is the same company that supplies joysticks for the Nintendo Switch joycon controllers.  And as we all know
column5: Nintendo is dealing with their own issues with joy-con drift.  But don’t go pointing fingers just yet
column6: it might not be the joysticks themselves that are causing drift.  And in other news
column7: EA is looking to patent a way for gamers to play their digital games via streaming immediately after purchase
column8: instead of having to wait hours for the game to download.  Pretty cool.  Switching gears from games to entertainment
column9: The CW’s Superman and Lois premieres tomorrow! We’ve got a short preview of what the super-couple have been up to since the events of Crisis on Infinite Earths.  It’s your Daily Fix! Thumbnail images from iFixIt

column1: 2021-02-22 20:13:23#tech#When Android 12 is coming to your phone#https://phandroid.com/2021/02/22/when-android-12-is-coming-to-your-phone/#https://phandroid.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/android-12-pixel-5-8-640x427.jpg#en#0.0#phandroid.com#There are quite a lot of new features that are hidden away in Android 12
column2: which is what we have come to expect.  Google has just released the first developer preview
column3: and there are some changes enabled by default
column4: and others that aren’t as obvious.  What’s new in Android 12 As is the case with every major version of Android
column5: Pixel devices get the first crack at the latest features.  Then
column6: phone makers will start to release beta versions of their own (in certain areas)
column7: before releasing the final updates.  But that still leads to the question of ‘When is my phone getting Android 12?’ Android 12 Release Schedule Last week marked the first release of the Android 12 developer preview
column8: meaning that we are still a few months away from any official beta release.  According to the official release schedule that was provided
column9: the first Android 12 beta could launch as early as May.  Expect to see the first Android 12 beta launch in May This would get Android 12 into the hands of more users
column10: allowing for bugs to be fixed and features to either be added or removed.  There will be a total of four betas released ahead of the final version.  If Android 11 was any indication
column11: then we could see the final version of Android 12 released in early September.  Google Pixel As is the case with every release of Android
column12: Google Pixel owners will receive Android 12 the day that it’s released.  Barring any setbacks
column13: we are expecting to see the first beta for Pixel owners arrive sometime in May.  Then
column14: the final release is slated for sometime later this year
column15: and according to the schedule provided by Google
column16: Android 12 should arrive for everyone in September.  These are the Pixel devices we are expecting to see receive Android 12: Pixel 3 / 3XL Pixel 3a / 3a XL Pixel 4 / 4 XL Pixel 4a / 4a 5G Pixel 5 Android 12 marks the end of support for the good ole’ Pixel 2 and 2 XL
column17: which was expected considering Google’s previous three-year commitment for device updates.  Samsung For years
column18: Samsung was one of the most egregious offenders when it came to providing timely software updates.  However
column19: over the last year or so
column20: Samsung has changed its tune.  This was evidenced by the “mad dash” to push the Android 11 update (via One UI 3. 0)
column21: before updating many of its handsets to One UI 3. 5.  The company has even just announced that it will be providing up to four years of security updates for smartphones
column22: starting with the Galaxy S10 line that was released in 2019.  As for Android 12
column23: there’s no real way to tell when the update will officially arrive for your smartphone.  We do know that almost any phone released starting in 2019 will receive the update.  Alongside the launch of the Galaxy Note 20
column24: Samsung confirmed that it will be sticking to three years of major Android releases for devices.  Based on the schedule for the Android 11 update
column25: we can expect to see devices starting to receive the update at the end of 2021
column26: and into the beginning of 2022.  These are the devices we are expecting to see receive Android 12: Galaxy S21 / S21+ / S21 Ultra Galaxy S20 / S20+ / S20 Ultra / S20 FE Galaxy Note 20 / Note 20 Ultra Galaxy S10 / S10e / S10 Lite / S10 Plus Galaxy Note 10 / Note 10+ / Note 10 Lite Galaxy Z Flip / Z Flip 5G Galaxy Z Fold 2 Galaxy A71 Galaxy A51 Galaxy A90 5G Galaxy Tab S7 / S7+ Galaxy Tab S6 / S6 Lite OnePlus Ignoring OnePlus’ budget lineup for a moment
column27: the company has a pretty solid track record for releasing stable versions of new Android releases.  For example
column28: Android 11 was released for Pixel owners on September 8th
column29: and it arrived on the OnePlus 8 and 8 Pro on October 10th.  Although older devices
column30: like the OnePlus 7 and 7T have seen mixed results due to buggy beta versions
column31: we can expect a quick turnaround from OnePlus for its newer handsets.  It’s also important to note that the Android 12 release could spell the end of official support for the OnePlus 6 and 6T.  These are the OnePlus devices we are expecting to see receive Android 12: OnePlus 7 / 7T / 7T Pro OnePlus 8 / 8 Pro / 8T OnePlus Nord Motorola A company that was once at the top of the list with software updates
column32: has slowly turned into one of the more frustrating companies.  Motorola launched the new Moto One 5G Ace
column34: and G Power earlier this year
column35: but all three handsets shipped with Android 10.  In fact
column36: when the company shared its plans for updating devices to Android 11
column37: it stated that many of those devices would not receive the update to Android 12.  Motorola has yet to share a roadmap of when it expects to release the Android 12 update for recently-launched products.  However
column38: it did confirm that both the Edge+ and Moto RAZR would be receiving the update.  So it’s just a waiting game until we find out a more concrete answer on the update schedule.  LG When 2021 is all said and done
column39: we wouldn’t be surprised if LG makes its official exit out of the smartphone game.  It’s been rumored and suggested that this would be the plan at some point
column40: even after showing off the LG Rollable at CES 2021.  Following that up
column41: a recent report claims that LG has reached out to its manufacturing partners for the Rollable
column42: requesting to pause production.  LG has fallen quite hard
column43: as it was once a provider of a great smartphone experience.  But it seems that the battle to keep up with the Samsung’s and Apple’s of the world has taken its toll.  The company has not given any indication as to when and/or if its recently-released smartphones will get an update to Android 12.  In the event that LG sticks around
column44: these are the devices would expect to see updated to Android 12: LG V60 ThinQ LG Wing LG Velvet Oppo When a new version of Android is introduced
column46: similar to what we see Google do ahead of the final launch.  Oppo is one of those companies that has been not only performing internal testing
column47: but also opens up a beta program for new versions of Color OS.  With Android 12
column48: we're expecting to see a similar schedule to what we have seen with the Android 11 release cycle.  Development will begin around now
column49: with a beta program to launch shortly after the final version of Android 12 is released.  This will be available for select devices (usually the higher-end models)
column50: before trickling down to more options from Oppo's lineup.  We wouldn't be surprised to see the first beta of Color OS (12?) released in September
column51: ahead of the final version rolling out in October
column53: and/or December of this year.  Xiaomi Xiaomi is still in the process of updating its vast array of devices to Android 11 (courtesy of MIUI 12)
column54: and there's a laundry list of smartphones left to go.  However
column55: that doesn't necessarily mean that Android 12 will be avoided altogether
column56: as we're sure the company is getting a head-start on the development process.  Whenever the next version of MIUI is announced
column57: it will likely either be MIUI 12. 5 or MIUI 13
column58: and will be based on Android 12.  The real question is when this will roll out to devices
column60: Android 12 wouldn't be arriving until sometime in early 2022.  Vivo One company that has a lot of pull in other areas of the world
column61: but doesn't have the greatest track record when it comes to updates is Vivo.  The company has shown that it's willing to push the envelope when it comes to hardware development
column62: but the software side is another story.  Thankfully
column63: it seems that Vivo is changing its tune a bit when it comes to its newer devices like the iQOO 3 5G.  Vivo has confirmed that the iQOO 3 will receive two major Android updates
column65: along with security updates for a total of three years.  Huawei Thanks to the trade ban in the U. S.
column66: Huawei's hand was forced when it came to developing its own software for its devices.  The company has pivoted to HarmonyOS
column67: which has been in development for a few years now.  However
column69: there were no immediate plans to switch the operating systems from Google's Android.  With that being said
column70: starting in April of this year
column71: Huawei devices will be released with HarmonyOS in-tow.  This means that future smartphones will not be powered by Android 12
column72: and unless something changes between Huawei and the U. S.
column73: HarmonyOS will be the way of the future for Huawei. #https://phandroid.com/2021/02/22/when-android-12-is-coming-to-your-phone/#mnhpMnQMG

column1: 2021-02-23 12:17:31#tech#Apple M1 Macs appear to be chewing through their SSDs#https://www.pcgamer.com/apple-m1-macs-appear-to-be-chewing-through-their-ssds/#https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/DhgmvxRdTf9uf9QbzMTxiY-1200-80.jpg#en#0.0#www.pcgamer.com#There's growing concern among Apple M1 Mac owners that the SSDs in their lovely new machines are being hammered by excessive swap file usage (via LTT Forums).  This could see the machines fail in less than two years
column2: if the numbers are correct
column3: and while this really is a worst-case scenario
column4: it still paints a worrying picture about the longevity of the new machines.  Something compounded by the fact that the SSDs are soldered on the mainboards
column5: which means replacing them isn't straightforward. Core to what's going on is the way in which SSDs work
column6: specifically the number of writes they can reliably support.  The flash memory on the drives can only be written to a certain number of times before becoming unstable.  There are plenty of systems in place to spread the load across all the memory cells
column7: but essentially there's a point where the drive has been written to so many times that it can no longer reliably hold the information. This is all summed up by the Total Bytes Written figure
column8: measured in terabytes (which is why it's also referred to as Terabytes Written).  This needs to be considered in the context of the length of the warranty
column9: which is generally five years. #https://www.pcgamer.com/apple-m1-macs-appear-to-be-chewing-through-their-ssds/#noV94HdfR

Use of Non-GAAP Financial Measures We have provided in this press release certain financial information that has not been prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States (“GAAP”).  Our management uses these non-GAAP financial measures internally in analyzing our financial results and believes that use of these non-GAAP financial measures is useful to investors as an additional tool to evaluate ongoing operating results and trends and in comparing our financial results with other companies in our industry
column156: many of which present similar non-GAAP financial measures.  Non-GAAP financial measures are not meant to be considered in isolation or as a substitute for comparable financial measures prepared in accordance with GAAP and should be read only in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements prepared in accordance with GAAP.  A reconciliation of our historical non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures has been provided in the financial statement tables included in this press release
column157: and investors are encouraged to review these reconciliations.  Annual revenue run-rate We calculate annual revenue run-rate (“ARR”) at the end of each month as the sum of: (1) the product of the current month’s monthly recurring revenue (“MRR”) multiplied by twelve (to prospectively annualize subscription revenue)
column158: and (2) the trailing twelve-month partner and services revenue
column160: such as one-time partner integration fees and store-launch services.  MRR includes BigCommerce platform subscription fees and invoiced growth adjustments as customers’ businesses grow past contracted order thresholds after a threshold has been met.  It also includes recurring professional services revenue
column161: such as recurring technical account management services and product training services.  Accounts with greater than $2
column162: 000 ACV We track the total number of accounts with annual contract value (“ACV”) greater than $2
column163: 000 (the “ACV threshold”) as of the end of a monthly billing period.  To define this $2
column165: we include only subscription plan revenue and exclude partner and services revenue and recurring services revenue.  We consider all stores added and subtracted as of the end of the monthly billing period.  This metric includes accounts that may have either one single store above the ACV threshold or multiple stores that together exceed the ACV threshold.  Accordingly
column166: this cohort would include: (1) customers on Enterprise plans
column168: and (3) customers with multiple plans that together exceed the ACV threshold.  Average revenue per account We calculate average revenue per account (ARPA) for accounts above the ACV threshold at the end of a period by including customer-billed revenue and an allocation of partner and services revenue.  Adjusted EBITDA We define Adjusted EBITDA as our net loss
column169: excluding the impact of stock-based compensation expense and related payroll tax expense
column173: changes in fair value of financial instruments
column174: and our provision for income taxes.  The most directly comparable GAAP measure is net loss.  Non-GAAP Operating Loss We define Non-GAAP Operating Loss as our GAAP Loss from operations
column175: excluding the impact of stock-based compensation expense and related payroll tax expense.  The most directly comparable GAAP measure is our loss from operations.  Non-GAAP Net Loss We define Non-GAAP Net Loss as our GAAP net loss
column176: excluding the impact of stock-based compensation expense and related payroll tax expense.  The most directly comparable GAAP measure is our net loss.  Non-GAAP Net Loss per Share We define Non-GAAP Net Loss per Share as our Non-GAAP Net Loss
column178: divided by our basic and diluted GAAP weighted average shares outstanding.  The most directly comparable GAAP measure is our net loss per share.  Free Cash Flow We define Free Cash flow as our GAAP cash flow from operating activities plus our GAAP purchases of property and equipment (Capital Expenditures).  The most directly comparable GAAP measure is our cash flow from operating activities.  Media Relations ContactRachael HensleyPR@BigCommerce. com ICR PR for BigCommerceBigCommerceICRPR@icrinc. com Investor Relations ContactDaniel LentzInvestorRelations@BigCommerce. com 607-351-7812 Source: BigCommerce Holdings

column2: Activision revealed that a ""large-scale"" Zombies mode called Outbreak is coming to Season Two of Call of Duty: Black Ops—Cold War.  Today it dropped a trailer showcasing the new mode in action
column3: along with a blog post detailing how it's all going to work. The trailer isn't much to write home about
column4: I don't think: Gunfire
column7: and generic one-liners delivered flatly by voice actors who sound like they're reading from the phone book
column8: while a classic rock remix plays in the background.  The blog post is a different story
column9: however.  There's plenty of narrative background if you're into that sort of thing
column10: and more practically there's also a breakdown of how the new mode will actually play. Squads of up to four players will be inserted into the Outbreak zone and given one of five objectives to investigate and complete.  How you approach these objectives is entirely up to you: You can take any route to get there
column11: and as much time as you like along the way.  Exploring the region will uncover rewards in loot chests
column13: and open up Trial Computers. More types of missions are expected to be added as Outbreak grows and evolves
column15: this is what you'll be getting up to:"#https://www.pcgamer.com/activision-details-how-call-of-duty-cold-wars-zombies-outbreak-mode-will-actually-work/#ewwo6OIuk
